text: CNS DEVELOPMENT I THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE SPINAL CORD Lecturer: Dr. T. Tshabalala Office No. 2P22, Second floor, Medical School Objectives Describe the process of neurulation  Development of the ependymal, mantle and marginal layers Development of the alar and basal plates Describe the function of the sulcus limitans “Retraction” of the spinal cord Describe the different types of spina bifida The development of the spinal cord The primordium of the brain and the spinal cord is the neural tube which forms during neurulation Neurulation Cranial and Caudal neuropores Primary brain vesiclesPrimary brain vesicles Neural tube Germinal cells Neural tube Ependymal Mantle Marginal Spinal cord development Primitive spinal cordPrimitive spinal cord Neuroblasts Glioblasts Primitive spinal cordPrimitive spinal cord Cells of the mantle layer proliferate to form 4 bulges Primitive spinal cordPrimitive spinal cordPrimitive spinal cord Sulcus limitans Primitive spinal cordPrimitive spinal cordPrimitive spinal cord L5 L1 L2 L3 L4 c L5 L1 L2 L3 L4 c L5 L1 L2 L3 L4 c L5 L1 L2 L3 L4 c End of term Adult NT Cauda equinaCauda equina Spina Bifida Cystica Occulta Spina bifida occulta Spina bifida with meningocoele Spina bifida occulta Spina bifida with meningocoele Spina bifida with meningomyelocoele Spina bifida with myeloschisisSpina bifida occulta Spina bifida cysticaMeningomyelocoele References Allan, J., Kramer, B. (2010). The fundamentals of human embryology. Wits University Press, Johannesburg. Sadler, T.W. (2006). Langman’s Medical Embryology. Lippincott Williams and Wilkins, USA. Moore, K., Persaud, T. (2010). The developing Human. Clinically oriented embryology. W. B. Saunders Company, Toronto.
